content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including lax screening, lack of in-flight security measures, and a failure of imagination among senior officials. The 9/11 Commission identified weaknesses in aviation security, including a lack of protocols for responding to hijackings and a failure of imagination among senior officials. Agencies had not taken specific actions to defend against potential threats before September 11, 2001. The 9/11 Commission found that before September 11, 2001, aviation security experts underestimated the likelihood of a suicide hijacking scenario. Congressional oversight of aviation security was lacking, with a focus on airport congestion and passenger service rather than specific actions to defend against potential threats. Congress concentrated on improving air service with a 'passenger bill of rights' instead of addressing security concerns. After September 11, 2001, Congress swiftly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address aviation security weaknesses. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all transportation modes. Key highlights included creating a federal security screener workforce. ATSA also granted TSA broad authority to assess and implement security measures across all transportation modes.
